quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Appetites instead of deadlines.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A core Shape Up reframing that replaces fixed scope-by-date planning with timeboxed investment decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A big focus on bringing design engine product together into a room to shape the plan versus writing long PRDs or trying to finalize designs before you start building.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a collaborative “shaping” workflow that challenges document-heavy handoffs and premature design finalization.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I've noticed more and more teams adopting the Shape Up method, and especially with AI starting to change how we work and build product, there's this shift coming in how product teams will operate.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points to an emerging trend and the pressure AI is putting on traditional product-development norms.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This episode is basically going to give you everything you need to give Shape Up a shot on your team or at your company to see if it fixes the problems that you're having shipping great products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames the discussion as a practical, trial-ready playbook for teams struggling to ship.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: A practical heads-up for SaaS builders on when enterprise requirements typically emerge so they can plan ahead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: Highlights a prioritization principle: reduce integration complexity to preserve time for core product work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: A scalable authorization mental model: optimize for both performance at scale and flexibility for edge cases.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their single API helps SaaS companies launch over 200 product integrations in weeks, not quarters.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Merge)
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for integration speed and scope that teams can use to evaluate build-vs-buy decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of Merge like Plaid, but for everything B2B SaaS.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Merge)
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that frames the product as an integration layer, simplifying how teams conceptualize the solution.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shape Up interest is rising
quotes.text: I mean, the book came out in 2019 and it's, I've been hearing more and more like, "Oh, we know somebody who's trying it or we're hearing it when we go talk to other companies." So, I think, it's a wave that's slowly building.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A concrete adoption signal (since 2019) that Shape Up is spreading via peer networks and cross-company conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shape Up interest is rising
quotes.text: what I started to learn pretty early on is that people don't like to talk about their struggles shipping.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Highlights a key cultural barrier to learning: teams hide shipping problems, limiting shared troubleshooting and best practices.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shape Up interest is rising
quotes.text: Especially CPOs and CTOs don't like to go on a public forum and say, "Our company isn't shipping or our engineering team is stuck, or our team is always lost in the weeds."
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Explains why leaders avoid public retrospectives, which can slow community learning and make change efforts feel isolating.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shape Up interest is rising
quotes.text: That's why I introduced Failure Corner on the podcast where it's like, "Okay, but tell me a time things didn't go well."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: An actionable tactic for creating psychological safety and extracting practical lessons: explicitly ask for failure stories.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shape Up interest is rising
quotes.text: It's a hard business and there's no perfect school either that produces expert product managers and CPOs and CTOs and stuff like that. So we're all trying to figure this out and we don't have a lot of sources, so there is a lot of struggle.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A grounding mental model: product leadership is learned in the field with limited formal training, so struggle is normal and expected.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond Basecamp: adoption in varied companies
quotes.text: I knew our inside story of we had some growing pains and we had to be able to formalize the way that we were working and shipping so that as we brought new people in that they could participate in that and we could stay fast.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Highlights the practical reason to formalize a product process: scaling participation without losing speed.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond Basecamp: adoption in varied companies
quotes.text: There are some really amazing cases of companies of very different characteristics from Basecamp, like VC funded, significantly bigger, very different pressures, different team structure, different skills who are doing it.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A concrete example that Shape Up can transfer across very different org contexts, not just Basecamp-like teams.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond Basecamp: adoption in varied companies
quotes.text: At the same time, there is also a lot of questions that are coming in my way because honestly, there are so few teams that are structured just like Basecamp, that there are a lot of gaps in the book of like, "Well, what about this, and what about that, and how do we do that in our situation?"
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning: adopting a method often requires adaptation because most teams won’t match the original environment.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond Basecamp: adoption in varied companies
quotes.text: So, a lot of my focus today is actually closing those gaps and helping people figure out how can I make this work for me or for our team?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Emphasizes an actionable adoption mindset: focus on tailoring the system to your team rather than copying it verbatim.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond Basecamp: adoption in varied companies
quotes.text: So then this led to this course that we made, which is called Shaping and Real Life. And well, yeah, the idea is the real life part, right? How do I make this work if my designers don't code? It's very contentious to get engineering time. You know what I mean? When there's all these different pressures that Basecamp didn't have.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Names the core “real life” constraints (non-coding designers, scarce engineering time, competing pressures) that teams must design their process around.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: early Basecamp constraints and urgency
quotes.text: But there was always this really intense urgency from both Jason and David, "We've got to get to something we can ship. We have to finish this and move on. We have to get to something that's done." There was just no tolerance for big things that got fuzzy and started to drag. There was always this sharpening to get to what is this thing really and when are we going to get to the end soon?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Highlights a practical operating principle: enforce urgency and actively de-fuzz work to reach a shippable finish line quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: early Basecamp constraints and urgency
quotes.text: And on top of that, even when we were building V1, David wasn't actually full-time as our only technical person. He was programming 10 hours a week. So, we had this really intense pressure of how can we really use David's time well?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A concrete constraint (10 hours/week) that forces prioritization and more efficient use of engineering time.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: early Basecamp constraints and urgency
quotes.text: We don't want to ever give something that this is the thing we want to build, and then it turns out not to be what we want and we have to throw it away and then come back again or you know what I mean? Those bad cycles of waste.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Captures an anti-waste mindset practitioners can apply by designing work to avoid costly build-throwaway-rebuild loops.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: early Basecamp constraints and urgency
quotes.text: So when do we get to see it? When do we get to try it? When do I get to put it into somebody's hands? So that combination, there was just so much urgency even though there was no outside pressure. You know what I mean? It was completely just let's say cultural energy of how do we keep getting somewhere and getting to something that we can celebrate and get excited about.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive point: urgency can be internally generated (cultural), not dependent on external deadlines, and tied to getting real usage fast.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping as collaborative problem-solving sessions
quotes.text: These little sessions where we would really figure out what the idea was and there would be this moment where you would have a few strokes of this Sharpie pen on a big pad of paper and all of a sudden you'd be like, "Oh yeah, that's the idea. That's the thing we want to go try to build."
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Highlights a lightweight, high-signal way to clarify a product concept quickly without heavy documentation.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping as collaborative problem-solving sessions
quotes.text: And for me, those sessions with Jason, they were these short, very, very intense sessions where you're trying to crack the nut together.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Defines shaping as a focused collaborative problem-solving mode rather than a drawn-out planning process.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping as collaborative problem-solving sessions
quotes.text: And that's the seedling of this word in the book shaping. What does it mean to do shaping? It wasn't sitting alone writing a document, it wasn't making a bunch of requirements.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Directly challenges conventional product planning norms (PRDs/requirements) as the primary way to define work.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping as collaborative problem-solving sessions
quotes.text: It wasn't making a beautiful Figma file to represent a concept that could maybe be a feature.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Warns against over-investing in polished design artifacts before the concept is truly understood and buildable.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping as collaborative problem-solving sessions
quotes.text: Very intensely collaborative sessions to figure out what the idea is and getting it sharp enough and crispy enough that we could very confidently get a yes from David.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Gives a practical bar for “done shaping”: the concept is crisp enough that an engineer can commit confidently.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping startup speed as the company grows
quotes.text: one big ingredient, we had an advantage also, which was that Jason and David hired so deliberately slowly, and this is a fortunate side effect of the fact that they didn't take investment money.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive lever—slow hiring enabled by not taking investment—as a way to preserve startup speed and culture.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping startup speed as the company grows
quotes.text: So there was never that moment of now's the moment when we grow. It was always one person. And then the organism adapts. One more person.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Offers a scalable mental model for growth: add people incrementally and let the system adapt between hires.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping startup speed as the company grows
quotes.text: And not only are there a lot of open questions here, we're not getting quick answers as we're asking.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Provides a practical diagnostic signal that a project is failing to converge: unanswered questions piling up without fast resolution.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping startup speed as the company grows
quotes.text: Oh, we're going to have to figure out when this goes well, why does it go well and what do we do differently and how do we formalize that so it's reproducible as we keep onboarding more people?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Captures the core methodology behind turning tacit “startup magic” into an explicit, repeatable operating system as the team grows.

quotes.topic_title: Core Shape Up ingredients: appetite, shaping, autonomy
quotes.text: We're going to go the other way around and we're going to say, "What is our appetite for this? What is the maximum amount of time we're willing to go before we actually finish something?"
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Reframes planning from estimating scope to setting a time budget (“appetite”) as the primary constraint.

quotes.topic_title: Core Shape Up ingredients: appetite, shaping, autonomy
quotes.text: So then what we found was that there was a lot of experimentation. We found that six weeks is the maximum that we can see into the future where we could actually say, "How do we work backward and figure out something we could build in that six weeks and really land it?"
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Gives a concrete planning horizon (six weeks) based on observed limits of predictability and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Core Shape Up ingredients: appetite, shaping, autonomy
quotes.text: So, this second piece is this work that we call shaping and the shaping work is, how do we actually take this fixed amount of time that we've given for ourselves and vary the scope?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Defines “shaping” as the practice of holding time constant and flexing scope to fit.

quotes.topic_title: Core Shape Up ingredients: appetite, shaping, autonomy
quotes.text: We don't have to do the sometimes called scrum, the paper shredder. That's where you take an idea and then you split it into 100 tickets, right, and you hope that it all glues together still after you've done that step. We don't want to do that.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional ticket-first approach by calling out how breaking work into many tickets can destroy coherence.

quotes.topic_title: Core Shape Up ingredients: appetite, shaping, autonomy
quotes.text: Instead, we want to have a whole idea, give it to a team so they see the whole, they really understand it, right? And then they can come up with their tasks and they can figure out how to track that and break it into pieces so they can actually take more responsibility.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Advocates handing teams a coherent “whole” and letting them own task breakdown to increase responsibility and autonomy.

quotes.topic_title: Partial adoption and common misapplication risks
quotes.text: You don't need to do any of it. So, this is where it helps to look at what's going wrong and what are we trying to fix? And then what do I want to bring into this, right?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A pragmatic adoption model: start from your team’s pain points and selectively adopt practices that address them.

quotes.topic_title: Partial adoption and common misapplication risks
quotes.text: Now, the thing that's tricky is that if you want that reality of the team happily buzzing and humming like some happy bee colony for this six weeks, they need to have a lot more clarity around what's the thing that we're solving, right?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Warns that autonomy and fewer rituals only work when the problem is clearly defined upfront.

quotes.topic_title: Partial adoption and common misapplication risks
quotes.text: And so when we start working backward from that, then what we see is that, "Oh, well, if we don't shape better, then the team isn't going to have the clarity that they need to take over that responsibility, so they can make choices and make decisions and make trade offs so that they can get to the end of this thing."
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Connects “shaping” to execution: better shaping creates the decision clarity teams need to manage scope and tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Partial adoption and common misapplication risks
quotes.text: And the worst is that sometimes see cases where people are like, "Okay, we're doing Shape Up. So, you guys are going to build the newsletter builder, okay? But you only get six weeks to do it. So use your fixed time, vary your scope and enjoy your responsibility." You know what I mean? Which is just cruel, right?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A concrete misapplication example: time-boxing a vague/oversized project and calling it empowerment sets teams up to fail.

quotes.topic_title: Partial adoption and common misapplication risks
quotes.text: Because I think I'll quote Bob Moesta, who's been on your show a couple times, "You can't put 10 pounds of crap in a five pound bag."
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A memorable constraint metaphor that cautions against assuming scope-cutting can make any project fit a fixed timebox.

quotes.topic_title: Why six weeks: maximum horizon, not a rule
quotes.text: So, actually, it turns out that the six-week is only a maximum and that's really where this number does some work for us.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Reframes the six-week cycle as an upper bound (a forcing function) rather than a fixed rule, changing how teams plan and commit.

quotes.topic_title: Why six weeks: maximum horizon, not a rule
quotes.text: If we think of six weeks as a maximum, that's going to force us to ask some really good questions to ourselves about what piece of this do we really think we can land?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A practical planning heuristic: use a hard ceiling to drive sharper scoping decisions about what can actually be finished.

quotes.topic_title: Why six weeks: maximum horizon, not a rule
quotes.text: Because if you try to say, in six months, we're going to ship this thing, you can't get your arms around all of the problems that have to get solved for an entire six-month chunk of work to actually happen.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Challenges long-horizon planning by pointing out it hides complexity and makes it harder to anticipate real work.

quotes.topic_title: Why six weeks: maximum horizon, not a rule
quotes.text: but if we set a ceiling at six weeks, we have a much better chance of, I think that's the size of something where we can actually shape it and surface enough unknowns and reveal that complexity before we're in the middle of it.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Explains why a six-week cap improves shaping: it helps expose unknowns early enough to avoid mid-project surprises.

quotes.topic_title: Why six weeks: maximum horizon, not a rule
quotes.text: So, then you get into a point where, well now, we're just sprinting and we're just taking one bite after the other. And then that's where we can land in that situation where we feel like, "Ah, I can never see the end of this. I just keep going back and saying, one more sprint, one more sprint, one more sprint."
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Warns that too-small timeboxes can create an endless-sprints trap where progress feels perpetual but completion stays out of sight.

quotes.topic_title: What happens when a bet misses the timebox
quotes.text: We can't just cut the scope and say, "Oh, well now, we managed to ship inside of six weeks." That's going to kill everybody's morale. Everyone's going to feel disappointed. We're going to feel like this wasn't really worthwhile.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Challenges the common “just cut scope” response by highlighting the morale and value-destruction risk when the cut removes what made the bet worthwhile.

quotes.topic_title: What happens when a bet misses the timebox
quotes.text: But what we can do is say, "We're not going to keep reinvesting in something that we don't understand."
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A practical decision rule for missed timeboxes: stop pouring effort into unclear work rather than extending blindly or pretending scope cuts solve it.

quotes.topic_title: What happens when a bet misses the timebox
quotes.text: So, let's take this out of build mode and bring this back into shaping mode, which might mean different people, a different conversation asking different questions, doing a different kind of work to suss out what is it that's fuzzy here? What is it that we couldn't see? What do we not understand? How do we get to the clarity that we need, so that we can actually say this thing is going to happen if we give it another whack.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Offers an actionable recovery loop when a bet misses: pause building and re-shape to regain clarity before recommitting.

quotes.topic_title: What happens when a bet misses the timebox
quotes.text: But when it comes to real product work, where there's some functionality that we have to figure out how to make it exist, we can't just cut the scope if we run out of time.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Draws a key distinction between simple tasks and real product development, where uncertainty makes “scope cutting” an unreliable escape hatch.

quotes.topic_title: What happens when a bet misses the timebox
quotes.text: You bring that person together with the product person who deeply understands the backstory of why this is an opportunity and what we're trying to solve with this. And then a designer in the room and they're whiteboarding and wrestling with each other to get to what's a version of this thing that we believe in that's real that we can actually finish in that time.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A concrete shaping-session recipe: the “knows where the bodies are buried” engineer + product + design collaborate live to shape something finishable within the timebox.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up in large orgs and cadence adapters
quotes.text: So, the key thing is actually that that time is pushing back at you and that you're being intentional about, what's my time budget that I need to shape into?
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A practical mental model for planning: treat time as a hard constraint that forces intentional scope shaping.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up in large orgs and cadence adapters
quotes.text: It can function in very large companies.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Counters the assumption that Shape Up only works in small startups by asserting it can scale to large orgs.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up in large orgs and cadence adapters
quotes.text: It is possible for engineering leadership, good engineering leadership untangles things, so we can work on this system without having to be thinking about this other system somewhere else.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for large orgs: reduce dependencies via architecture/infrastructure “untangling” to enable autonomous cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up in large orgs and cadence adapters
quotes.text: I've seen cases where they've decided on a four-week plus two-week or so they'll do five-week and then one week of cool down in between and then they time it so that it adds up to a quarter.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A concrete “cadence adapter” example for aligning Shape Up cycles to quarterly planning without adopting quarterly execution.

quotes.topic_title: Shape Up in large orgs and cadence adapters
quotes.text: And when you are consistently saying, "We said we were going to do that and it's finished, without excuses and without, well, maybe another few more months or we're working at it," that's what everyone wants to see is that movement.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A pragmatic strategy for earning autonomy in big-company reporting: consistent delivery matters more than matching the org’s cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping outputs: diagrams over PRDs or Figma
quotes.text: So, what we need to do in a shaping session when it's going well is we come out with some kind of drawing or diagram where engineers, product, and design are all looking at that and they're saying, "We understand that. I know exactly what to go build."
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Defines the core deliverable of a successful shaping session: a shared, buildable diagram that aligns product/design/engineering.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping outputs: diagrams over PRDs or Figma
quotes.text: If it's shaped well, you can usually describe it in less than 10 moving pieces.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Provides a practical rule-of-thumb for judging whether a shaped concept is clear and constrained enough to build.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping outputs: diagrams over PRDs or Figma
quotes.text: So, what you can see here is it's not like, what is a calendar? It's not a calendar. It's a two-month dot grid with scrolling agenda view underneath and the ability to hit new when you're looking at an empty space to create something in what you're viewing.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A concrete example of shaping by narrowing scope to a specific, buildable solution instead of a broad feature category.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping outputs: diagrams over PRDs or Figma
quotes.text: Exactly. So, because the thing where it goes wrong. If we're going to commit engineering time and it's like we believe there's some way to see empty spaces, but the way is a question mark, it's a really risky way to spend that time.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Warns against committing engineering cycles to an undefined solution, highlighting why shaping must remove key unknowns.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping outputs: diagrams over PRDs or Figma
quotes.text: There's still a million interesting creative tasks there in the actual high fidelity design in the code. There's so many things to solve there, but that is something that they can all hold in their heads and understand and work on.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Clarifies that shaping isn’t over-specifying; it’s creating enough shared clarity to enable creative execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of it as mission control for your entire product organization.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for consolidating product operations into a single source of truth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Unlike rigid point solutions, ProductCentral powers, everything from resourcing to voice of customer to road mapping to launch execution.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an end-to-end workflow approach (not a single-tool fix) that product orgs can apply when evaluating systems.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And because it's built on Airtable's no-code platform, you can customize every workflow to match exactly how your team works. No limitations, no compromises.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to prioritize adaptable tooling that fits team workflows rather than forcing process changes to match software constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: if you get too detailed, the engineers and designers on the team are just like, "What the hell? You're just telling me what to build. That sucks. I don't want that kind of work."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that overly prescriptive specs can reduce ownership and motivation in cross-functional teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, is the solution to that the engineering lead was super involved and detailed, and the design lead was super involved, and so you can trust that you're not just the code monkey building the thing they told you to build?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Poses a practical team-structure/process hypothesis: detail can work if it’s co-created by engineering and design leadership to preserve autonomy.

quotes.topic_title: Right level of detail and team seniority
quotes.text: That's really interesting. I got to tell you, the dominant failure case that I see in the real world is always, again and again, not enough detail.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Contrarian takeaway that the bigger practical risk is under-specifying rather than over-specifying.

quotes.topic_title: Right level of detail and team seniority
quotes.text: The amount of detail that the team is going to feel helps them is a dial that we can turn that depends on who's on the team.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A simple mental model: treat detail level as a tunable control based on team composition.

quotes.topic_title: Right level of detail and team seniority
quotes.text: So, if you have a more junior person who's on the build team and then you have a more senior engineer who's involved in the shaping, they can make that junior engineer much more successful with additional detail.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for matching specificity to seniority to increase execution success.

quotes.topic_title: Right level of detail and team seniority
quotes.text: That junior person is, when they don't know how to do it, they're not going to ask because they don't want to show that they don't know, and they're going to hide the fact that they're lost and it's going to blow up later in the project.
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode (hidden confusion) that more upfront guidance can prevent.

quotes.topic_title: Right level of detail and team seniority
quotes.text: And on the other hand, if they are given more guidance, they're going to be able to be successful. They're going to learn about this is how this person who knows well, kind of approached it and then in the next round or a few projects later, you can dial it back and say, "Well, let's give less detail and see how they handle it."
quotes.speaker: Ryan Singer
quotes.context: A practical coaching loop: start with more detail to teach, then reduce detail over time to build autonomy.
